hints_html:
Recall that the y-value of the center of mass is given by

\(\displaystyle \overline y = \frac{\iint_Ry\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}{\iint_R\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}\)

To find the integration boundaries of the variables \(\displaystyle x,\ y\) for the region \(\displaystyle R\) a sketch is very helpful

On the sketch we see that the region \(\displaystyle R\) is bounded by the functions \(\displaystyle y=2-x\) and \(\displaystyle y=2-2x\)

If we do not want to split the region into two integrals, we must integrate with respect to \(\displaystyle x\) first. Find the \(\displaystyle y\)-depending boundaries for \(\displaystyle x\), such that

\[\begin{aligned} \underline{\ \ \ \ \ \ \ }&\leq x\leq \underline{ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ }\\ 0&\leq y\leq 2\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex:
Recall that the y-value of the center of mass is given by

$\displaystyle \overline y = \frac{\iint_Ry\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}{\iint_R\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}$

To find the integration boundaries of the variables
$\displaystyle x,\ y$ for the region $\displaystyle R$ a sketch is very
helpful

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]

On the sketch we see that the region $\displaystyle R$ is bounded by the
functions $\displaystyle y=2-x$ and $\displaystyle y=2-2x$

If we do not want to split the region into two integrals, we must
integrate with respect to $\displaystyle x$ first. Find the
$\displaystyle y$-depending boundaries for $\displaystyle x$, such that

\begin{align*}
\underline{\ \ \ \ \ \ \ }&\leq x\leq \underline{ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ }\\
0&\leq y\leq 2
\end{align*}
hints_raw:
Recall that the y-value of the center of mass is given by

<math>\displaystyle \overline y = \frac{\iint_Ry\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}{\iint_R\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}</math>
To find the integration boundaries of the variables <math>\displaystyle x,\ y</math> for the region <math>\displaystyle R</math> a sketch is very helpful

:[[File:Math200Dec11Q6.jpg|300px|Sketch of R]]


On the sketch we see that the region <math>\displaystyle R</math> is bounded by the functions 
<math>\displaystyle y=2-x</math> and 
<math>\displaystyle y=2-2x</math>


If we do not want to split the region into two integrals, we must integrate with respect to <math>\displaystyle x</math> first. Find the <math>\displaystyle y</math>-depending boundaries for <math>\displaystyle x</math>, such that

<math>\displaystyle\begin{align}
\underline{\ \ \ \ \ \ \ }&\leq x\leq \underline{ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ }\\
0&\leq y\leq 2
\end{align}</math>
sols_html:
Since the region of integration is a triangle with vertices \(\displaystyle (1,0),\ (2,0),\ (0,2)\) the region is bounded by the function \(\displaystyle y=2-x\) and \(\displaystyle y=2-2x\), see sketch

We want to integrate with respect to \(\displaystyle x\) first, hence, solving for x, the integration boundaries become

\[\begin{aligned} \textstyle\frac12 (2-y)&\leq x\leq 2-y\\ 0&\leq y\leq 2\end{aligned}\]

and the region is \(\displaystyle R=\{(x,y)\in\R^2|\ 1-\frac{y}{2}\leq x\leq 2-y,\ 0\leq y\leq 2\}\)

To calculate \(\displaystyle \overline y = \frac{\iint_Ry\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}{\iint_R \rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}\) which is the \(\displaystyle y\) coordinate of the center of mass, we calculate at first the integral in the numerator.

\[\begin{aligned} \iint_R y\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A &= \int_0^2\int_{1-\frac{y}{2}}^{2-y}y^3\;\text{d}x\text{d}y\\ &= \int_0^2y^3(2-y - 1+\frac{y}{2})\;\text{d}y \\ &= \int_0^2(y^3-\frac{y^4}{2})\;\text{d}y\\ &= \frac{2^4}{4} - \frac{2^5}{10} = \frac{4}{5}\end{aligned}\]

The integral in the denominator is very similar

\[\begin{aligned} \iint_R \rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A = \int_0^2\int_{1-\frac{y}{2}}^{2-y}y^2\;\text{d}x\text{d}y = \int_0^2(y^2-\frac{y^3}{2})\;\text{d}y = \frac{2}{3}\end{aligned}\]

Hence

\(\displaystyle \overline y = \frac{\frac{4}{5}}{\frac23} = \frac65\)
sols_raw:
Since the region of integration is a triangle with vertices <math>\displaystyle (1,0),\ (2,0),\ (0,2)</math> the region is bounded by the function <math>\displaystyle y=2-x</math> and <math>\displaystyle y=2-2x</math>, see sketch

:[[File:Math200Dec11Q6.jpg|200px|Sketch of R]]

We want to integrate with respect to <math>\displaystyle x</math> first, hence, solving for ''x'', the integration boundaries become
:<math>\displaystyle\begin{align}
\textstyle\frac12 (2-y)&\leq x\leq 2-y\\
0&\leq y\leq 2
\end{align}</math>

and the region is <math>\displaystyle R=\{(x,y)\in\R^2|\ 1-\frac{y}{2}\leq x\leq 2-y,\ 0\leq y\leq 2\}</math>

To calculate <math>\displaystyle \overline y = \frac{\iint_Ry\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A}{\iint_R \rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A} </math>
which is the <math>\displaystyle y</math> coordinate of the center of mass,
we calculate at first the integral in the numerator.

<math>\displaystyle\begin{align}
 \iint_R y\rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A &= \int_0^2\int_{1-\frac{y}{2}}^{2-y}y^3\;\text{d}x\text{d}y\\
&= \int_0^2y^3(2-y - 1+\frac{y}{2})\;\text{d}y \\
&= \int_0^2(y^3-\frac{y^4}{2})\;\text{d}y\\
&= \frac{2^4}{4} - \frac{2^5}{10} = \frac{4}{5}
\end{align}</math>


The integral in the denominator is very similar

<math>\displaystyle\begin{align}
 \iint_R \rho(x,y)\;\text{d}A = \int_0^2\int_{1-\frac{y}{2}}^{2-y}y^2\;\text{d}x\text{d}y
= \int_0^2(y^2-\frac{y^3}{2})\;\text{d}y = \frac{2}{3}
\end{align}</math>

Hence

<math>\displaystyle \overline y = \frac{\frac{4}{5}}{\frac23} = \frac65</math>
statement_html: Let R be the triangle with vertices (0,2), (1,0), and (2,0). Let R have density \(\displaystyle \rho(x,y) = y^{2}\). Find \(\bar{y}\), the y-coordinate of the center of mass of R. You do not need to find \(\bar{x}\).
statement_latex:
Let R be the triangle with vertices (0,2), (1,0), and (2,0). Let R have
density $\displaystyle \rho(x,y) = y^{2}$. Find $\bar{y}$, the
y-coordinate of the center of mass of R. You do not need to find
$\bar{x}$.
statement_raw: Let R be the triangle with vertices (0,2), (1,0), and (2,0). Let R have density <math>\displaystyle\rho(x,y) = y^{2}</math>. Find <math>\bar{y}</math>, the y-coordinate of the center of mass of R. <b>You do not need to find <math>\bar{x}</math></b>.
